content.description: Up the shallow dihedral to a difficult dyno, then a harder deadpoint (crux) to move up and rightwards through the overhang.
content.location:
Route #2 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description: Climb the obvious hand crack (Route 6). Mid way climb left on a small seam and up a steep face/crack with strenuous gear placements and a couple of burly moves. Nice climbing with the major detraction being a close proximity to the hand crack.  Still worth trying for the moves.  The old Matt Samet guide book referred to this route as "incredible", so quality is in the mind of the climber. You be the judge.
content.protection: Micro to medium cams, wires; the hangers are long gone so forget the draws.
content.location:
Route #5 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description: Start as for Route 8, then right up good cracks.
content.location:
Route #9 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description: Climb a right-leaning fist crack to ledge, then up a left-trending finger crack/seam.
content.location:
Route #8 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description:
A beautiful line that ascends an aesthetic, mildly-overhung hand crack in a shallow dihedral, Route 6 is one of the finest crack climbs in White Rock. It's well worth the annoying approach to Pajarito Gorge, just to climb this one. 

  Start out with an improbable boulder problem up the thin crack directly below the obvious splitter. This opening section is arguably the the technical crux of the climb, but is well protected by finger-sized cams. After surmounting this initial trickiness, cruise up a lower-angled finger crack to a stance below the steep handcrack. Crank strenuous moves to get established in the hand crack, and do your best to hang on as sustained 5.9 and 5.10 jamming leads all the way to the cliff top.
content.protection:
The pro is great, and available nearly everywhere. You will need to build a gear anchor at the top. 

  Rack:   BD cams from .3 to #3, as well as a TCU/C3 or two. Some doubles in the .75 to #3 range are useful (you don't necessarily need doubles on all these pieces). Stoppers optional.
content.location:
Route #6 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      . 

  On the left side of the Main Wall. Pretty much as far left as you'd want to go without a rope. Look for the obvious, steep splitter in a shallow dihedral. A few feet to the right is an overhung hands/fingers crack in a slot, which kind of looks like a cobra (this is "Bunghole Slot", Route 7). A few feet right of that is another obvious right-trending fist crack (the start of Route 8 and 9).

content.description: Up the left-leaning flake, then a left-trending fingercrack.
content.location:
Route #4 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description: Climb the slabby corner (crux) for 25 feet and join route #4.
content.location:
Route #3 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description: Climb 2 smooth handcracks in a dihedral, then straight up.
content.location: Farthest right route at the crag, north/east of the downclimb.

content.description:
Route 20 is an excellent route to help develop solid jamming skills. 

  Start in a dihedral split by a nice wide-hands crack. The crack is an tough size to jam for most, but this section is made much easier with help of other, more friendly, features and good feet. Awkwardly clamber over the huge wedged block to gain a excellent rest. The next section, a steep, left-leaning hand crack with poor feet, presents the crux. Follow this strenuous crack to the top.
content.protection: Well protected. Bring a standard rack of nuts and cams to a #3 camalot. Doubles on hand-sized pieces (e.g. #1 and #2 camalot) would not go unused. You will need to build a gear anchor at the top.
content.location:
Right of Route 19, which is just north/east (i.e. climber's right) of the downclimb.  

  Route 20 climbs the cracks below a huge, imposing block. Above the block is a platform with a wide crack on the right, and a left-leaning hand crack on the left. The route finishes with the hand crack.

content.description: Climb a finger crack for 20 feet, then up and right on easier terrain.
content.location: Right of Poseidon Adventure.

content.description: Up a slight overhanging headwall (don't fall or you'll end up in the big cactus!), than up and right following the big left facing corner. At the top step first left, than right around the final overhang (crux).
content.protection: Top rope can be set with trad gear.
content.location: Spot the shiny bolt on Gorgonzola. This route follows the corner just to the right.

content.description:
With fun climbing and good gear, Route 14 is a great "first 5.9" for the aspiring leader. Not as tough as many of the 5.9 leads at the Playground, for instance. 

  Begin with moderate moves up a low angle dihedral, aiming for the featured and steep headwall above. This airy headwall presents the crux, but is easier than it looks due to an abundance of positive pockets and edges. Continue up similar, but slightly easier, terrain to the top.
content.protection: Well protected. A single set of nuts and cams to a #3 camalot is sufficient. You will need to build a gear anchor.
content.location:
Route #14 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      . 

  To find Route #14, it's perhaps easiest to locate Route #16 ("Gorgonzola"). Spot the shiny bolts on Gorgonzola, then the thin crack just to its left (the thin crack is Route #15). Route #14 climbs the first obvious line left of the thin crack, starting in a blocky dihedral and finishing on a well featured face. If you spot a low bolt on a slab, leading to a flaring fingercrack, this is for Route #13, and you've gone too far.

content.description: Climb the seam/face left of Gorgonzola. Tricky!
content.location: Just left of Gorgonzola

content.description: Climb the slab with a fingercrack in it, then up a steeper corner.
content.location:

content.description: Poseidon Adventure stands out from the typical 5.10 White Rock crack because of its unique and very coolÂ crux.Pick out the really improbable steep corner with a finger crack in the back: that's the crux (it's just right of an obvious wide crack that arches left). Get up to it by climbing a slab or the hand crack to its right; have a good rest on a slab before the business. Take a step up the wide crack, stem to the right, and pull through the very overhanging crux, which is well-protected with cams. Easier cracks finish the climb to the top.
content.protection: 1 set cams from TCUs to 3", 1 set nuts.
content.location: This climb is just to the right of the scramble/downclimb. You will see an obvious left-arching wide crack: Poseidon Adventure goes up the steep overhanging thin crack just right of this.

climbs.name: Gorgonzola
climbs.fa: Bob D'Antonio, Chris Vandiver, Jean DeLataillade

content.description: The face between route 15 and route 17. Kinda contrived. As of about 10 years ago, the hangers were missing from the bolts [but hangers are on them as of 9/2010].
content.protection: Bolts [w/ hangers as of 9/2010]. TR probably a good idea.
content.location: Farthest right bolted route on the main PG wall.

content.description: Traverse over the gorge on choss (exposed!) and climb up the dihedral.
content.protection: Best to toprope if you don't want to die.
content.location:
Route #1 in the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description: A challenge exercise in jamming multiple off sizes with a flaring pod thrown in as an extra bonus.  The meat of the climb is short and begins at a pod halfway up.  Exiting the pod and establishing in the crack above is the crux. Not climbed as much as deserved perhaps because of the birds tendency to use this climb as a latrine.
content.location:
Route #7 on the               

Pajarito Gorge main cliff.  Crappy photo from before the era of digital cameras...      .

content.description: This is a mostly south-facing basalt crag with trad and sport routes that are exposed and fun. This gets sun most of the day and is subject to winds because of the nature of the location.
